maturity_levels.L1: L1 At lower maturity-  tracking is seen; data is often siloed
maturity_levels.L2: L2 At intermediate maturity, metrics become real-time, integrated across systems, and used routinely in decisions (e.g., predictive maintenance and FPY by VIN).
maturity_levels.L3: L3 At advanced maturity Impact is seen on metrices (OEE uplift, energy per unit, COQ reduction, ROCE) and can demonstrate that AI/automation is self-optimizing key KPIs across plants.

categories.name: Operations & Flow
metrics: Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE) and OEE uplift
Baseline OEE and the percentage increase attributed to digital / smart factory initiatives (target uplift is often the lead success metric).​
Targetted Sprints (4-6 weeks)
1. Micro stoppages identification & Elimination
2. Change overs > TAKE Time - identification & Elimination
3. Unplanned Downtime - identification & Elimination
Supporting metrics: throughput vs plan, schedule adherence, and changeover time reduction.​
Flow, responsiveness, and stability
Throughput per line, takt adherence, line balance index, and average queue/buffer times between key processes.​
On-time units produced (actual vs plan), re-plans per week, and average time to recover from a disruption or major stoppage.​

categories.name: Quality & Traceability
metrics: First Pass Yield (FPY) and quality yield
FPY per critical station, scrap and rework rate, ppm defects, and trend of these indicators after digitalization.​
Warranty claims and field failure rates linked back to manufacturing data (evidence of effective traceability and analytics).​
Traceability and zero-defect capability
Coverage of VIN/serial-level traceability for critical parameters (what % of operations and parameters are traceable).​
Number of issues detected in-line vs at end-of-line or in the field (earlier detection indicates higher maturity).​

categories.name: Assets, Maintenance & Energy
metrics: Downtime, reliability, and predictive impact
Mean time between failures (MTBF), mean time to repair (MTTR), planned vs unplanned downtime, and average downtime per machine/line.​
Percentage of assets under predictive maintenance and the reduction in unplanned stops attributed to predictive models.​
Energy and resource efficiency
Energy consumption per unit produced, peak demand, and specific consumption by shop (body, paint, GA, etc.).​
Material utilization and waste/reject cost per unit, tracked and improved through smart manufacturing use cases.​
People, Digital Ways of Working & Safety
Workforce digital adoption and efficiency
Percentage of operators/engineers actively using digital work instructions, dashboards, or mobile apps daily.​
Labor productivity (units per labor hour) and improvement linked to automation, cobots, and decision-support tools.​
Safety and ergonomics
Reported safety incidents per employee and % reduction targeted via smart factory solutions.​
Near-miss reporting rate and closure time on safety actions, showing proactive and data-driven safety culture.​
Supply Chain, Integration & Business Impact
Supply, logistics, and integration maturity
On-time delivery (OTD) to customers, schedule adherence to customer call-offs, and inventory turns for key materials.​
Degree of integration: % of processes/orders fully flowing digitally across ERP–MES–WMS–QMS–PLM (can be scored as a maturity metric, not just a KPI).​
Financial and strategic outcomes
Manufacturing cost per unit, cost of poor quality, and their improvement after smart factory deployments.​
Return on capital employed (ROCE) or similar, used as a top-level success metric for smart factory programs.​
